question.title: Piping output to the correct place when running unit tests in a CI pipeline
question.body:
I have been working on a project that sends data to a vendor by executing a jar from inside our kotlin code (see: Loading a jar file into a kotlin unit test for more details). I implemented what I thought was a solution using java.lang.ProcessBuilder. All my tests are passing when I run them from my local build. When I try to run those same tests as part of the deployment process to our gitlab CI pipeline however, I'm getting strange results.

My log output from the deployment job looks like this:

[INFO] -------------------------------------------------------
[INFO]  T E S T S
[INFO] -------------------------------------------------------
Picked up _JAVA_OPTIONS: -Xms256m -Xmx1024m
[INFO] Running edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.Test
ERROR 2025-05-13 15:10:21,841 [main] edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.executeJavaJar: Picked up _JAVA_OPTIONS: -Xms256m -Xmx1024m
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Exception: Too many args
    at Main.main(Main.java:10)
ERROR 2025-05-13 15:10:22,431 [main] edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.executeJavaJar: Picked up _JAVA_OPTIONS: -Xms256m -Xmx1024m
[ERROR] Tests run: 4, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 1, Time elapsed: 2.779 s <<< FAILURE! -- in edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.Test
[ERROR] edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.Test.test execute java jar with tmp -- Time elapsed: 0.266 s <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: 
test execute java jar failed with error: Picked up _JAVA_OPTIONS: -Xms256m -Xmx1024m
    at edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.Test.test execute java jar with tmp(test.kt:108)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:566)
    at java.base/java.util.ArrayList.forEach(ArrayList.java:1541)
    at java.base/java.util.ArrayList.forEach(ArrayList.java:1541)
[INFO] 
[INFO] Results:
[INFO] 
[ERROR] Failures: 
[ERROR]   Test.test execute java jar with tmp:108 test execute java jar failed with error: Picked up _JAVA_OPTIONS: -Xms256m -Xmx1024m
[INFO] 
[ERROR] Tests run: 4, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 1

The function responsible for executing the jar looks like:

internal fun executeJavaJar(dp: INT295DependencyProvider, workingDir:String, jarFile:String, args:List<String>): Either<Throwable, String>
{
    val j = dp.journalFactory("edu.bucknell.eventmanagement.int295.executeJavaJar")
   return runCatching {
       val cmdArgs: MutableList<String> = mutableListOf("java", "-jar", jarFile)
       cmdArgs.addAll(args)
       ProcessBuilder(cmdArgs).directory(File(workingDir))
           .redirectOutput(ProcessBuilder.Redirect.PIPE)
           .redirectError(ProcessBuilder.Redirect.PIPE)
           .start()
    }.fold({
        it->
        val output = IOUtils.toString( it.inputStream, Charsets.UTF_8)
        val error = IOUtils.toString( it.errorStream, Charsets.UTF_8)
       if(error.isNotEmpty())
       {
           j.error(error)
           Exception(error).left()
       }
       else {
           j.debug(output)
           output.right()
       }
    }, {
        error->
        error.left()
    })
}

and the actual test:

@Test
fun `test execute java jar with tmp`()
{
    mockContext(300).value().let { context ->
        testInt295DependencyProvider(context).let { dp ->
            javaClass.classLoader.getResourceAsStream("HelloTest.jar").use { stream ->
                assertNotNull(stream)
                val inputFile = createTempFile(prefix = "hello", suffix = ".jar").toFile()
                Files.copy(stream, inputFile.toPath(), StandardCopyOption.REPLACE_EXISTING)
                
                executeJavaJar(dp,".",
                    inputFile.absolutePath, listOf("abc")).fold({
                    fail("test execute java jar failed with error: ${it.message}")
                }, {
                        output->
                    println(output)
                    assertNotNull(output)
                    assertThat(output).isNotEmpty
                })
            }
        }
    }
}

I suspect it has something to do with the pipeline redirects in ProcessBuilder. However I can't find any information about how to properly configure the process builder to route output in a CI environment. Can anyone shed some light on where I'm going wrong with this?

Update: I did some more digging and narrowed in on the issue but I'm still not sure what to do. After adding some additional logging, I determined that the java class being executed isn't actually producing any errors. However, something in the CI deployment is writing text '_JAVA_OPTIONS="-Xms256m -Xmx1024m"' to the errorStream. When I look at the contents of that stream for my test, I'm getting a false positive as a result.

Update 2: I found the line in the deployment script that is causing the problem and was able to reproduce the failure when running the script locally. If I run this bash script:

#!/bin/sh
# shared gitlab runner host based script
export _JAVA_OPTIONS="-Xms256m -Xmx1024m"

mvn test -Dmule.testingMode=true -Dpackage=edu.bucknell -DfailIfNoTests=false -Dsurefire.skipAfterFailureCount=1

It will reproduce the issues I'm seeing in the CI environment. I can work around the issue by manually stripping that variable out of the ProcessBuilder environment

       val pb = ProcessBuilder(cmdArgs).directory(File(workingDir))
           .redirectError(ProcessBuilder.Redirect.PIPE)
           pb.environment().remove("_JAVA_OPTIONS")
           pb.start()

But I'm not any closer to understanding the root cause.

answers.body:
The message "Picked up ..." is hard-coded to be printed by the java command if it finds a relevant environment variable. The source code shows a statement not guarded by any if:

  jio_fprintf(defaultStream::error_stream(),
              "Picked up %s: %s\n", name, buffer);

The fact that it prints on stderr doesn't mean there is an error. Quite often, command-line tools print on stderr just to avoid polluting stdout.

The only way to avoid having java print this message is to unset the _JAVA_OPTIONS variable. So, what you're doing as a "workaround" is actually the way to do it.

question_comments.body: I would like to know why the errorStream contains text even when there is no error and what I can do to fix this.
So what exactly is your question? Is it why you are getting the message about _JAVA_OPTIONS? What do you mean by "root cause" - cause of what?

I realize that. The problem is, I'm looking at the errorStream to determine whether the jar executed successfully. If there is random 'information' text in there it will cause false positives in my tests.
The error is actually "Too many args" which is produced by the main function of the jar file. The "Picked up _JAVA_OPTIONS" message is not an error, it's just informational.
